text: today we're presenting our webinar on using domain verification with Amazon simple email service I'm Jen Steele and
I'm the product marketing manager for Amazon SES we also have two members of the Amazon SES team to field your
questions at the end of our webinar Chris wheeler our lead technical program manager and Justin christs our lead
developer today we have a pretty simple
agenda to make sure we're all on the same page I'll go through a brief overview of Amazon SES and how to get
started then we'll jump into verification in detail including why you need to verify your sending domain or
email address how to verify email addresses how to verify your domain including route 53 integration on
verifying your domain and troubleshooting common domain verification issues finally I'll briefly
go through our support resources and then the team and I will be taking your questions so what is Amazon simple email
service we are a cloud-based email sending service you can pay as you go we
require no contracts we have the reliable redundant Amazon infrastructure and we're built to require little to no
infrastructure on your part which will allow you to scale your email sending quickly and easily now let's take a look
at how SES works a client application acting as an email sender makes a request to Amazon SES to send email to
one or more recipients if the request is valid Amazon SES composes an email
message based on the request parameters and then queues it for delivery the message is routed over the Internet to
the recipients Internet service provider or ISP which then delivers the message to the recipients inbox if the
recipients email address does not exist the ISP sends a bounced notification to Amazon SES the service then forwards the
notification to the sender a recipie
who does not want to receive the message can register a complaint with their ISP by clicking their spam button an ISP
which chooses to set up a feedback loop sends the complaint to Amazon SES and we then forward it to the sender let's take
a minute to talk about our pricing we have a flat rate of $0.10 per thousand email messages as I mentioned earlier we
don't have any minimum commitments or subscription fees we do charge for data transfer out but your first gig to each
month is free if you choose to send email with attachments the attachments
are billed separately at 12 cents per gig and like many AWS services we do
have a free tier if you're an Amazon ec2 user you can send two thousand messages each day for free when you call SES from
your ec2 instance directly or through AWS elastic Beanstalk we have a fair number of customers who can operate
entirely within this free tier shinola
now let's talk about how to get started with the Amazon SES and let's look at
where domain verification falls into the grand scheme of things here I'll review how to sign-up briefly show you where
verification fits and look at how to send a test email then I'll go through

verification I just wanted to see you to see where it fits okay so first you need

minutes when you first have an AWS account you'll be in the Amazon SES

really this is where you're making sure you can get set up you know you're in the sandbox by the big yellow box at the

period your next step is to verify a new sender a domain or an email address
as I said before we're going to dive into this a little more later in the presentation so I'll just mention here

sending test email you can send it a test email in several different ways you

email address or domain from which you want to send the test email click the send a test email button and fill out
the form to send the email so as I mentioned before right now we're in the
sandbox let's talk about what that means for sending your test email when you're
in the sandbox you can only send from or to verified email addresses basically
you can only email yourself sorry that's verified email addresses or domains you
have other limitations as well you have a tiny quota 200 messages per day and you can only send one email message per
second you're in the sandbox here to run a proof-of-concept it's a testing environment
once you have production access that looks a little different when you're in
the SES production environment your quota will be 10,000 messages per day and will continue to rise as you see
send your production email through SES you will also see your TPS the number of
emails you can send per second continue to rise as well although you start at 5:00 and while you can still only send
from verified email addresses and domains you can send to any email address in the world to get production
access you have to request it again you can see that you don't have production
access if you only have a 200 message per day quota and you have a big yellow box at the top of your management
console to request production access click on the request production access button clicking this button will take
you to the Amazon SES production access forum please fill it out completely
production access requests take up to one business data process and if our team has any questions for you we'll get
in contact with you please note that we will be looking at production access for
the account you're currently logged into when you fill out this form if you have multiple AWS accounts please make sure
you're logged in to the correct one before filling out the form it will automatically fill in the email address
associated with the logged in account so you can double check it that way once we
have processed your request we will send you email confirmation or any questions we have to that address the primary one
associated with that AWS account the one that was filled in here however if you
don't regularly check that account there's an easy way to tell whether you have production access just check your
management console or call the get send quota API a quota of more than 200
messages per day means that your production access has been granted and this is what the management console
looks like you can see that you've moved up to a production quota of 10,000 messages per day and the big yellow box
asking you to request production access or verify a new sender is gone when you
when your management console looks like this screenshot you can send email to any email address no recipient
verification necessary but of course you'll still need to verify any new sender address through the same process
that we looked at before and that we'll look at shortly because that is after all what this webinar is about once you
have production access send your production email through SES by sending as much of your production email as you
can through SES you'll find that you're sending quota will increase naturally
our final getting started step is to send email and grow your quota we offer
several different ways for you to send email via Amazon SES and you should use whatever is easiest to integrate into
your systems you can send via our SMTP interface or through one of two different api's send email and send raw
email and as I said before once you've integrated your systems into Amazon SES
and you're sending your reproduction email you'll start to see your quota grow now if it's not growing quick
enough or if for some reason you can't set up your systems to send some of your of your
production email through it you can random you sorry you can manually request a higher quota via the extended
access request form I've included a link to that form here and you can also get to it right from your management console
as we'll see later in the presentation ok now that you have a better idea of
how to get started with Amazon SES let's talk about what we're really here to do talk about verification I'm going to
talk about why we require verification email verification and domain verification including the route 53
integration then we'll talk about unverified own and troubleshooting a few common domain verification problems so
we commonly get asked why why do we require customers to verify they're sending identities well first it's a
proof of ownership we need to make sure you are who you say you are and as a
result it produc protects legitimate sending no phishing believe me Amazon is very sensitive to this as our ISPs to
protect your sending we need to do everything in our power to protect legitimate sending it also helps protect
our customers brands this is similar to preventing phishing but in this case we just want to make sure if you want to
send from a particular domain that you have access to either a mail box on the domain or that domains DNS which usually
means that you are legitimately associated with that brand all of this proof and protection helps to keep
Amazon SES s IP address reputation high which helps increase deliver ability for
all of you our customers so let's look
at verifying email addresses what you'll want to do in a few cases such as if you do not have access to your domains DNS
or if you can't wait up to 72 hours for DNS records to propagate before you
start sending your email in through Amazon SES please note that to use email
address verification you must have a mailbox associated with a verified email address as you'll see and you'll see why
in a couple of slides to verify your email address go to your AWS man
console click on verified senders and click the verify a new email address button fill your email address into the
dialog that a box that appears and click the verify this email address button
then you go to the inbox for the address you're verifying and find that verification email click on the URL or
copy and paste it into your browser in order to verify the email address you'll get to a thank-you page telling you that
you're ready to start using that email address with SES if it's been a long time since you've sent that email sorry
excuse me if it's been a long time since you sent that address the verification email you
might get an error message when you try to click the link if that's the case just go back into the management console
and re-enter that email address for verification if it has been an hour since you requested that your email
address be verified and you have not received this email there are two things that you should do to troubleshoot first
you should check your spam folder verification emails sometimes get stuck in there the second is that you should
make sure that the email address you're trying to verify is able to accept external mail ok now let's talk about
the real reason we're here domain verification you will need to verify each sending domain or sub domain
from which you wish to send verifying is domain does not automatically verify
it's subdomains so if you want to send from both you'll need to verify both for
example if I want to send via Amazon SES from both amazon.com and aws.amazon.com
I'll need to verify both of them note that you're sending domain or subdomain
consists of everything to the right of the @ sign in the email address so they will rarely if ever contain WW like your
website address does to start the domain verification process go to the esta SES
tab of your AWS management console go to verified senders select the domains tab and click the verify a new domain button
in the box that appears type in the domain or sub that you want to verify and click verify
this domain a window will appear that will give you the information that you
will need to put into the DNS settings of that domain we verify your domains via a txt or txt record we check to make
sure that you have a txt record in your DNS with the values that we provided and we consider your domain to be verified
if that record is there so take the information from this window and create the txt record in your DNS settings you
should note that it can take up to 72 hours for DNS information to propagate and for your domain to successfully
verify however it usually takes only a few hours so as you can see in this
screenshot the domain that I just put in for verification is now on my domains tab with the status of pending
verification once Amazon SES detects the text record in my DNS the status will
change to verified and I'll receive an Amazon SES domain verification success confirmation from Amazon Web Services if
it has been more than 72 hours and we have not detected the presence of a text record with the values that we provided
we will change the status to failed and you will receive an Amazon SES domain
verification failed email from Amazon Web Services if that happens click the retry link next to the failed
status notification that you'll end up seeing here in the management console this will reinitiate the domain
verification process then setup the text record with the new information if you
need to retrieve the text record information for your domain simply go back into the domains tab here click on
the domain and the text record information will appear in the section below the one you see here to refresh
this screen and check your status click on the refresh button in the upper right corner you don't have to use the
management console to use domain verification however you can use domain verification programmatically via these
API actions verify domain identity starts the process for you and we'll return the text record
info that you need get identity verification attributes will tell you the status of your domain verification
and return the text record information as well lists identities will list all verified domains and email addresses
attached to your account and delete identity will allow you to delete a verified email address or domain you can
read more about all of these in the Amazon SES API reference so let's look
at how this works with Amazon route 53 integration now to start the process click on the verify and new domain
button the same way we did before in the box that appears type in your domain or
sub domain just like we did before and click the verify this domain now instead
of copying the text record information that displays if you see it click the use route 53 button in the lower right
hand corner of this of this dialog box
you'll select the hosted zones you want to update and click the Create record
sets button note that I only have one hosted zone here but you may may see multiples if you then go into the hosted
zone or zones for which you created record sets you'll see the text records and and their values will be the ones
generated by Amazon SES as you see here please note that if you use the Amazon
SES API to call us to set up domain verification you will need to use the Amazon route 53 API to create the record
set for your domain from here the process is the same Amazon SES checks periodically to see if the information
is here and will let you know the status of the verification removing a verified
domain is a straightforward process simply select a domain in your AWS management console and click the Remove
button we confirmed that you want to
delete the verified domain and you will no longer be able to send from that domain if you click the yes delete
sender button so now that we know how to set up and
remove verified domain I wanted to talk a little bit about troubleshooting by
and large the biggest issue that people have been having with domain verification is either not setting up
the text record in their DNS or in setting it up incorrectly so if your
domain verification is in a failed state and you've gotten the domain verification failed email from Amazon
Web Services then look at your dns info is the text and exort dns record present
and then make sure it's in the right format so you check it and then you
retry the verification again if it's in the failed state you can actually click retry verification right there in your
AWS management console if you're getting a verification an error when you try to
send your email double-check the state of your domain verification is it
pending is it failed you can check the DNS record and if necessary retry
verification or simply wait until verification has gone through now I want
